column2: The Kennecott Copper Corporation said its annual meeting had been adjourned from tomorrow to June 20-- the fourth adjournment since the May 2 annual meeting at which shareholders of the big copper company voted to defeat the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in a proxy fight for control of Kennecott.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)-- California received the must patents of any state, but Delaware residents, individually, were the most inventive, according to annual statistics issued today by the United States Patent Office.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The Supreme Court cleared the way today for American Nazis to march through the heavily Jewish Chicago suburb of Skokie.

The phasing out of the scandal-ridden Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx, the city's only secure detention facility for children charged with delinquency, was recommended yesterday by a mayoral task force.
WASHINGTON, June 12--With only 16 members present, the House of Representatives tiptoed into the electronic age today by allowing live radio broadcasts of its regular proceedings.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--Based on current indications, this year's grain harvest in the Soviet Union could exceed 205 million metric tons, up at least 4.9 percent from 1977, the Agriculture Department said today.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, called today for the abolition of the spending limit in Presidential election campaigns and advocated the use of private contributions in addition to Federal funds in such campaigns.

SOMEWHERE, somehow, long ago the spark of life was ignited, ultimately populating the Earth with creatures from bacteria to whales. While recent discoveries have defined many of the mileposts along this path, deep uncertainty remains concerning the central question: How probable or improbable was the lighting of the spark?
"If you can't fight 'em, join'em" is a byword that clearly transcends national bounds, at least where high-risk arbitrage is concerned.
Uniroyal, one of the nation's largest producers of footwear, announced yesterday that after 86 years it was getting out of the footwear business in the United States.
A Federal bankruptcy judge in Jackson, Miss., has approved a plan liquidating Bankers Trust Company for 50 cents on the dollar.

MOSCOW, June 12--The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that an American woman assigned to the United States Embassy here had been arrested last July as she planted a cache of spy equipment, including ampuls of a lethal poison, on a bridge over the Moscow River.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., June 11 (UPI)-- Workers righted a derailed tank car carrying liquid butane today and rolled it to safety, averting the possibility of an explosion. The authorities then reopened the 16-square-block area from which more than 100 people were evacuated after the derailment last night of four cars on a Union Pacific freight. No one was injured in the accident, which a railroad spokesman blamed on a worn switch.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 12--In the final of the New York State tennis championships for women at Beach Point Club today, 12-year-old Kathy Horvath of Hopewell Junction defeated Lisa Levins of Massapequa, L.I., 4-6, 6-2, 6-3.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 12-- Peacefully integrated in the rolling green hills here, the undulating Marin County government center designed by Frank Lloyd Wright gives no sign of the turmoil that has been happening inside: Last Thursday 400 county workers were notified that passage of a property tax limitation to the State Constitution two days earlier appeared to have cost them their jobs.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Representatives of the major New York City banks and municipal pension funds refused today to commit themselves to increased lending to the city despite pressure from the Senate Banking Committee, which is considering loan legislation for the city.

Talks on a contract between New York City and its police force broke off after 13 minutes yesterday, with the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association calling on Mayor Koch's administration to remove all its 22 so-called "giveback" demands.

Algur Hurtle Meadows, one of the country's most successful independent oilmen, died Saturday in a Dallas Hospital as the result of an automobile accident the night before in Duncanville, Tex. He was 79 years old and lived in Dallas and Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Commerce Department has lifted the controversial secrecy order that its Patent and Trademark Office had imposed on publicly funded research on computer security conducted at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Government officials confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Congressmen from the Northeast and Great Lakes states who have been able to win some realignment of Federal aid formulas to help their region said today that they wanted an in-depth study of the capital needs of their areas in the hope of capturing more Federal grants.

MADRID, June 12--Last-minute lobbying by Spanish banking interests appears to be delaying the Government's issuance of a major decree that would permit foreign banks to open branches and subsidiaries in Spain for the first time since the civil war.

OTTAWA, June 12--Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today introduced in Parliament his long-awaited proposal for a new Canadian constitution, incorporating a bill of rights and guarantees to linguistic minorities, among other changes.

BETHPAGE, L.I., June 12--The Grumman Corporation, seeking to cut back its dependence on military contracts, today announced the $7.5 million sale of a device to preserve fresh fruit and produce for long periods without freezing.

The auction for Rod Carew has begun. By midnight Thursdy, the major league trading deadline, baseball's best hitter expects to have been dealt by the Minnesota Twins to one of five contenders--the New York Yankees, the California Angels, the Texas Rangers, the Kansas City Royals or the Boston Red Sox.

General Dynamics shares rose sharply yesterday to sell at their best level in a decade after the company settled its dispute with the Navy over submarine contracts. The stock rose 4 3/8 points to 67 .

C.R. Palmer, chairman of Rowan Companies, said the company planned to announce its position today regarding a proposed offer of $26 a share for its 10 million shares outstanding by a unit of the Chicago Bridge and Iron Company, a transaction valued at $260 million.
TEL AVIV, June 12--Israeli settlers in the Jordan Valley village of Mehola repelled a band of Arab raiders this morning and killed one of them, the military command reported.

IT WAS, as one balletomane put it, a weekend to see pretty young things doing pretty young things. The youngest dancers of American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet were out in force on Saturday and Sunday afternoons. The results augur well for the future.

While the leaders of the largest New York City municipal unions spoke generously of further sacrifice before the Senate Banking Committee yesterday, the heads of the police union were threatening strike, "legal picketing" and "rule-book" action to win a higher pay raise than all other city workers.

ALBANY, June 12--Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak withdrew as a candidate for re-election today, charging that Governor Carey was inaccessible and unwilling "to fulfill his obligations" of office. Her move, made as Mr. Carey was formally announcing his candidacy for re-election, threw the state Democratic Party into turmoil.

HAVANA, Tuesday, June 13--President Fidel Castro charged early today that President Carter had been "manipulated and deceived" by elements in his own Administration concerning last month's invasion of Zaire's Shaba Province by Katangan troops. He blamed Zbigniew Brzezinski, the President's adviser on national security.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Soviet Union has made a proposal for placing equal limits on Eastern and Western military forces in Central Europe that Carter Administration officials said today could be an important breakthrough in the long-stalled negotiations over a mutual reduction of forces in that area.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters)-- President Carter has no plans for a meeting with President Anwar el-Sadat, White House officials said today.
ALBANY, June 12--Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak withdrew as a candidate for re-election today, charging that Governor Carey was inaccessible and unwilling "to fulfill his obligations" of office.

ABERDEEN TOWNSHIP, June 12 (AP)--If the residents here want to get mail addressed to Aberdeen Township, instead of Matawan Township, they are going to have to vote on a Postal Service change, a White House spokesman said today.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 12--Jabbing his hands into the air and then crunching them suddenly into fists, a pharmacologist described today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich how one of the tests the prosecution is relying on can reach out and grab minute amounts of curare in a sample.

TELEVISION, which appeared for two shows Sunday night at the Bottom Line, was one of the first of the New York new wave rock bands, along with Patti Smith, the Ramones and Talking Heads. But although Television's debut album, "Marquee Moon," made many ...

ST. VINCENT, Minn., June 12 (AP)-- Three escaped prisoners who allegedly stole a plane and flew from Nebraska to North Dakota early today were captured tonight by United States Border Patrol agents, the authorities said.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Attorney General Griffin B. Bell lost a round today in his attempt to prevent the Socialist Workers Party from learning the identity of some of the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who worked as informers within the party's ranks.

If anyone has earned the right to call the West to a moral reckoning, it is Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. The high courage and conviction which sustained him in the Soviet Gulag have captured the admiration of all free people.

CHICAGO ONE of the real highlights of second North American International Dance Festival, which closed at Chicago's Civic Opera House on Sunday, has been the closeup it provided of Mikhail Baryshnikov at work.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has named a former managing editor of Newsday, Arthur G. Perfall, as its director of public affairs. Mr. Perfall was previously senior vice president of the European Bank and Trust Company. He joined Newsday as a reporter in 1954. While there, he organized and directed an investigative team that won the Pulitzer Gold Medal in 1970.
LOVE and marriage are subjects that can soften even the most hardened of sensibilities, and they recently moved a court to poetry in hand ing down a tax decision.

WASHINGTON, June 12--On the platform in the White House briefing room, Robert S. Strauss was exultant. "A major breakthrough," he called the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's decision to raise prices by roughly 3 percent and not more.

WASHINGTON, June 12--President Carter announced today that the United States would not employ nuclear weapons against countries that have promised not to develop such weapons or are not allied to a nuclear power.

GILBERTSVILLE, N.Y., June 9--There is no home delivery of mail here, the story goes, because the turn-of-the-century postmaster, who owned a jewelry store near the post office, reckoned it would be good for business to give folks an excuse to come downtown every day.
BERKELEY, Calif.--On a steep, wooded hillside looking toward San Francisco Bay, a score or so of men and women, most of them young and casually dressed, are looking for the ultimate limit of matter.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to block charges that the Washington Redskins' football team enjoyed an illegal monopoly as tenant of the capital's Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium.

A proposal for a $35 million pediatric wing at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center that has been bitterly criticized by Nassau County hospitals as a waste of health resources is expected to be approved today by the New York State Office of Health Systems Management.

The First Boston Corporation yesterday became the third major dealer to cut fees on its commercial paper business, following the lead of Goldman, Sachs Company and Salomon Brothers, which lowered their prices earlier this spring.

WHEN 80-year-old Algur H. Meadows, founder and chairman of the General American Oil Company of Texas, was killed in an auto accident last Friday after a golf game, the prospects for his company changed dramatically.

TOKYO, June 12 (Reuters)--Japan's densely populated main island of Honshu was rocked today by the strongest earthquake to hit the country in 14 years, and at least 21 people died and 350 were injured as buildings and power lines crumbled. At least two others were reported missing.

YEREVAN, U.S.S.R. HENRIK IGITIAN is a 46-year-old Armenian art critic who describes himself as a "dicator." What he has done with his power is to create the only museum of modern art in the entire Soviet Union--a first-rate collection of abseract and Expressionist paintings by Armenian artists here and abroad.

WHEN Universial's newest mechanical shark-"Jaws 2"--swims into 500 theaters on Friday, it will be dragging behind it more T-shires, bubble-gum cards, beach towels, coloring books and loaves of sliced white bread than any other new movie in the history of a fantastically promotionminded industry.

Prices of live cattle futures closed down as much as 1.5 cents a pound yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Because cattle futures were up about a half-cent a pound shortly after the opening, the day's decline was roughly 2 cents, or $800 per contract of 40,000 pounds.

CINCINNATI, June 12 (UPI)--Rick Reuschel and Ken Holtzman, making his first appearance since his acquisition Saturday from the New York Yankees combined for a four-hitter tonight in pitching the Chicago Cubs to a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

The Senate got its second woman yesterday when Maryon P. Allen was sworn in by Vice President Mondale to fill the seat of her husband, James, who died suddenly 12 days ago. The new Democratic Senator from Alabama was escorted to Mr. Mondale's desk by the state's retiring senior Senator.

LOS ANGELES, June 12--Business leaders in California may still be uncertain, but some other experts in the state are beginning to conclude that Proposition 13, the controversial initiative that will slash property tax collections by 60 percent on July 1, may not be a disaster for the state's economy after all.

Witnesses for New York City testified yesterday that provisions of a 1975 wagedeferral agreement affecting municipal employees limited the city's liability for repayment to a period ending this June 30.

BRIGHTON, England--The closest thing to a royal toy maker in the service of Queen Elizabeth II is 78-year-old Yootha Rose. For nearly 25 years, Miss Rose has been making her distinctive hand-carved and hand-painted carousels and doll houses for the children of the Royal Family. Her latest project is a miniature zoo for Master Peter Phillips, the 7-month-old son of Princess Anne.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that newspapers can no longer acquire radio or television stations in their own communities, affirming a policy developed by the Federal Communications Commission to promote diversity of viewpoint and limit the concentration of economic power.

She now is helping the Soviet Union sell $20 million worth of stamps to finance the 1980 Olympic Games, but that cool, detached smile brought back memories. Can Lyudmila Turischeva, once perhaps the world's greatest gymnast, be through at the age of 25?

BASEL, Switzerland, June 12--The Carter Administration was urged by a leading European banker today to back its economic policies with "hard cash" by borrowing "substantial" quantities of foreign currency abroad.
A FRENCH modern-dance company called the Ballet Blaska made its New York debut at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night and it featured some surprising aspects.

M.C. Whatmore, chairman of Cowles Communications, said the company had made a further submission to the Internal Revenue Service in support of the request for rulings that Cowles's previously announced plan of liquidation and dissolution would constitute a complete liquidation for tax purposes.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 12--After a bitter runoff campaign that has become a test of public confidence in Gov. David Pryor, Arkansas Democrats vote tomorrow to choose a nominee for the United States Senate seat of the late John J. McClellan.
Steel production for the week ended June 10 rose to 2.8 million tons, up 1.9 percent from the 2.749 million tons produced the previous week, the Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, June 12--First in private and then more and more in public, Lieut, Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak let it be known that she has been unhappy over her relationship with Governor Carey from the beginning of their term of office in 1975.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Soviet Union has made a proposal for placing equal limits on Eastern and Western military forces in Central Europe that Carter Administration officials said today could be an important breakthrough in the long-stalled negotiations over a mutual reduction of forces in that area.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest, steel company, announced yesterday that it was increasing prices by about 3 percent, a level that won immediate praise from two of the Carter Administration's top inflation fighters, who urged the rest of the steel industry to act similarly.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--President Carter is expected to name Bella S. Abzug as co-director of a new Federal advisory committee on women, despite objections from his wife and daughter-inlaw.

The dollar fell in Tokyo, then plunged to a record low against the Japanese yen in London yesterday and registered broad losses in other foreign-exchange trading overseas and in New York. The Associated Press reported.

THE annual deluge of awards for creative advertising continued last night at the One Show, spon sored by the One Club in the Rainbow Room. The big agency winners were Della Femina, Travisano Partners and Scali, McCabe, Sloves. Each collected four gold medals.

Lynn Redgrave, the British actress, testified yesterday at a National Labor Relations Board hearing considering allegations that the extra fees levied against her and some other foreign actors by Actors Equity constitute an unfair labor practice.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The Supreme Court cleared the way today for American Nazis to march through the heavily Jewish Chicago suburb of Skokie.

NEWARK, June 12--The Essex County Prosecutor announced today the arrest of 11 juveniles and eight adults on drug charges after a two-month undercover investigation of drug traffic in the Bloomfield and Irvington public schools.

ON the one hand, the Hippocratic oath is quite specific: "I will not give to a woman an abortive remedy." On the oth hand, most new medical school graduates do not take the Hippochatic oath; they subscribe instead to a resolution of the World Health Organization that refers not at all to abortion.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that newspapers can no longer acquire radio or television stations in their own communities, affirming a policy developed by the Federal Communications Commission to promote diversity of viewpoint and limit the concentration of economic power.
BERKELEY, Calif.--On a steep, wooded hillside looking toward San Francisco Bay, a score or so of men and women, most of them young and casually dressed, are looking for the ultimate limit of matter.

Tyco Laboratories, a manufacturer of fire sprinkler systems and underwater cable, announced yesterday that it had sold its entire holding of more than 2 million shares of Cutler-Hammer Inc. to the Eaton Corporation for $115.8 million.

BUENOS AIRES, June 12--Though the Italian team in the World Cup soccer championship here has been heavily criticized at home and accused of living on the memories of victories in Italy in 1934 and Paris in 1938, it carries the only unbeaten, untied record into the second round that begins Wednesday.

A bid by the president and another executive of the Bund Buyer, a privately held publishing company, for a temporary injunction against certain actions by the companys chairman and others, was rejected yesterday in a New York State Supreme Court ruling.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP)--The artificial creation of rat insulin may point the way to mass production of human insulin and an unlimited supply of the hormone that keeps many diabetics alive, researchers say.

WASHINGTON, June 12--The White House was aware of the contention by President Fidel Castro of Cuba that he had tried to stop the invasion of Zaire's Shaba Province by Kantangans based in Angola, but chose not to make it public. Jody Powell, the President's press secretary, said today.
A major show of ancient Greek art from Greek museums, covering more than 3,000 years, will take place next year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

BONN, June 12 (Reuters)--A fire bomb exploded at the Embassy of Zaire here early today, causing slight damage. Leaflets scattered in front of the embassy were signed by a group calling itself the People's Army of the Oppressed in Zaire, Foreign Brigade. A similar fire bomb was placed two months ago, apparently by the same group, the police said.
If your taste in Father's Day gifts runs to expensive jewelry, keep in mind this distinction: The insurance on Dad's jewelry could cost about double the premium on Mom's comparable set of stones.
If you haven't picked up your copy of "Chemistry of Acetylenes" yet, you'd better hurry. The price recently jumped from $92.25 to $125 and, inflation being what it is, it will probably jump again.

LOS ANGELES--Before two visitors had a chance to knock, the door of Ronald Reagan's comfortable house in Pacific Palisades swung open as if triggered by an electric eye. But it was Mr. Reagan himself who peered out at his startled guests.

CROTON POINT, N.Y. THE county dump here is taking in the jagged, soggy stuff of overslaked appetites and broken dreams by the truckload. And at a pause in the dusty, back-road traffic Dominick Rossetti enters like Fellini, with his producer, his cameraman, and 20 other production and advertising agency people trailing in to create new dreams and appetites, this time for a sweatsock.

MONTREAL, June 12--To be continued. That was the only result today after an all-day meeting of the National Hockey League's board of governors concerning the future of the New York Islanders and the Cleveland Barons.

Dozens of elderly vacationers on a package tour of South Jersey shore resorts were stricken with apparent food poisening last night after eating lunch at the Smithville Inn colonial village near Atlantic City, authorities reported.

The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 11 restaurants for violations of the health code and reported that three establishments had corrected earlier violations and that one had been closed for failing to do so. The restaurants were listed as follows.

GILBERTSVILLE, N.Y., June 9--There is no home delivery of mail here, the story goes, because the turn-of-the-century postmaster, who owned a jewelry store near the post office, reckoned it would be good for business to give folks an excuse to come downtown every day.

EASTMEADOW, L.I., June 12--Floral Park High School defeated South Side of Rockville Centre, 3-2, today in the opener of the two-of-three-game Nassau County baceball championship series at Elsenhower Park. The second game will be tomorrow night, with a third Thursday, if necessary.

One week after its debut, and after a wave of negative reviews around the country, ABC News has put the scalpel to its prime-time magazine series, "20/20," dismissing the two hosts and eliminating many of the departmental features.
The Newspaper Guild of New York yesterday resumed negotiations with The Daily News with the help of Federal negotiators and set a new strike deadline, 2 P.M. today, against The News.
Citizens Southern Realty Investors said as of noon yesterday that it had only about $7.5 million aggregatge principal amount of its old debentures tendered for exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 12--In a ruling that could have broad impact on other kinds of food production, the Supreme Court held today that poultry producers who subcontract the growing of their stock do not enjoy the immunity from antitrust prosecution that Congress gave to farmers.
"THE deceleration program is accelerating," Stuart E. Eizenstat said at a business meet ing in Washington last week, and nobody laughed.
HOUSTON, June 12--A former assistant chief of the Houston police was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of perjury, obstruction of justice and extortion.

Austin T. Cushman, retired chairman and chief executive officer of Sears, Roebuck Company, the world's largest retail organization, died yesterday in a hospital in Pasadena, Calif. He was 76 years old and lived in San Marino, Calif.

PORTLAND, Me., June 12--This state's cluttered nine-man race for the governorship will be trimmed somewhat tomorrow as Maine voters select Republican and Democratic candidates to oppose three independents in the fall general elections.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The Food and Drug Administration proposed today restrictions on sleeping aids that would end over-the-counter sales of daytime sedatives.
HACKENSACK, June 12--The State Energy Department asked the State Legislature today for a 90-day extension of the July 11 deadline for submission of New Jersey's new 10-year energy master plan.

HACKENSACK, June 12--Jabbing his hands into the air and then crunching them suddenly into fists, a pharmacologist described today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich how one of the tests the prosecution is relying on can reach out and grab minute amounts of curate in a sample.

FLANKED by a brace of aides and led by a beaming maitre d', Ed Koch strode purposefully through a popular restaurant here one evening last week, bestowing his smile indiscriminately along the way like a flower girl strewing rose petals down a wedding aisle.

The New York City police have begun a new--and unannounced--drive to clean up the Times Square area by tripling the number of uniformed foot patrolmen in the neighborhood on most nights. The move has increased the size of the force to over 100 officers.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--Retail sales declined 0.2 percent in May, mainly as a result of a drop in auto buying from the strong auto month of April, the Commerce Department said today.

JERUSALEM, June 12--For the second time in 10 days, the Israeli Cabinet met today to discuss American inquiries on policy aimed at reviving the stalled Middle East peace talks. But the Cabinet did not reach a decision on how to reply to Washington.
The following are excerpts from Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's commencement address at Harvard:
PANAMA, June 12--"A leader should be aloof." Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid told a visitor in Miami recently. "He should be untouchable. They carry the Pope on a bier so you can't get too close.

To celebrate their 21st anniversary a few weeks ago, Richard and Karen Wolfe, who live in Riverdale, had dinner at an East Side restaurant, went to the theater and rented a chauffered limousine for the entire evening.

TOKYO, June 12 (Reuters)--Japan's densely populated main island of Honshu was rocked today by the strongest earthquake to hit the country in 14 years, and at least 21 people died and 350 were injured as buildings and power lines crumbled. At least two others were reported missing.

Chester M. Lewis, director of archives and former chief librarian for The New York Times, will receive the Special Libraries Association's Hall of Fame/1978 Award for his introduction of new library technology at The Times, including installations of the first prototype microfilm reader.

The Taft Broadcasting Company said that it had reached a definitive agreement to purchase the stock of Channel 20 Inc., a unit of the Superior Tube Company, for $13.5 million. The final transaction is subject to approval from the Federal Communications Commission. Channel 20 operates WDCA-TV in Washington, D.C.

Tenneco Inc., a Houston-based conglomerate, announced yesterday that its directors and the directors of Albright Wilson Ltd., the British chemical giant, had reached agreement on revised terms--increasing the offering price--of Tenneco's proposal to acquire full ownership of the British concern. Tenneco acquired 49.8 percent of Albright Wilson in 1974.

MILWAUKEE, June 9--After 13 years of litigation, a Federal court here has ruled that, at least since 1950, decisions, by Milwaukee public school officials "were undertaken with an intent to segregate students and teachers by race."
W.R. Grace Company announced it had agreed in principle to acquire the assets of Evans Chemetics Inc. for an undisclosed amount of Grace common stock.

Prices in the credit markets rose moderately early yesterday as traders speculated that there might be a pintsized advance this week before the Federal Reserve made its next move to tighten credit. Later, the advance faded.

NEWARK, June 12 (AP)--A research company that provides ready-made term papers to college students settled a civil suit with the United States Atterney's office here by agreeing to limit its advertising, open its customer records to professors and change other business practices.

Following are excerpts from opening statements to the Senate Banking Committee hearing by Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association; Jack Bigel, consultant to city labor unions, and Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of teachers. The remarks were transcribed by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)-- Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal described the inflation rate today as a "worrisome thing" and predicted it would be about 6.5 percent to 7 percent for the full year.

David Klein, who began the Dav-El Livery with one car on the opening night of "Follies," in 1971, now runs a fleet of 30 limousines as well as what he believes to be the city's only school for limousine chauffeurs. Some of the tips he gives to prospective Dav-El drivers are:

David R. Berkowitz was sentenced yesterday to the maximum prison term, 25 years to life, for each of the six "Son of Sam" slayings carried out over a year in which his nighttime forays cast a pall of fear over the young.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (Reuters)-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed today that Britain appoint an American-style special prosecutor to investigate new reports of police brutality in Northern Ireland.

Luigi Vecchia, a construction worker from Tappan, N.Y., did not hesitate to drive 50 miles and pay $60 for four tickets and $8 for parking so that he and his family could watch on a screen a soccer game that was played about 5,000 miles away.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steel company, announced yesterday that it was increasing prices by about 3 percent, a level that won immediate praise from two of the Carter Administration's top inflation fighters, who urged the rest of the steel industry to act similarly.

Representative Bruce Caputo of Yonkers declared officially yesterday for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor and said his role would be expanded beyond the "nonjob" that the incumbent says she is abandoning.
Almost 400 demonstrators who had gathered near the United States mission to the United Nations yesterday to protest the nuclear arms race were arrested and taken to Police Headquarters.

Suburbia triumphed over the inner city when the New Jersey-Westchester representatives defeated the New York city team in the Grand National zonal championship final last weekend in Philadelphia by 28 International match points.

ATLANTA, June 12 (UPI)--Betty Talmadge, the former wife of Senator Herman Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, conceded yesterday that she accepted $500 and a crystal set valued at more than $150 at two of the Senator's annual birthday parties.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)--Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, who last week implored Congress not to take a "meat ax" to his budget in a drive against waste, said the department can absorb a $1 billion cut without reducing any services.
Myron J. Greene, senior partner in the law firm of Millard, Greene Udell, 450 Park Avenue, died Saturday in his home, 303 East 57th Street, after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

A unit of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and three other companies have agreed to refund to the British Post Office the equivalent of $16.5 million following an investigation into their price practices for telephone cable from 1963 to 1974.

MOSCOW, June 12 (AP)--Muhammad Ali arrived in Moscow today. He said he hoped to meet Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader; spar with Soviet boxers and possibly stay to train for his rematch with Leon Spinks.

WHILE the television halfhour might seem limited to carrying little more than situation comedies soap operas and game programs, the form can still emit occasional glimmerings of additional energy. On public television.

CAVENDISH, Vt., June 12--In a dispute over the way his books were brought to publication in the West while he was an embattled dissident author in the Soviet Union in the late 1960's and early 1970's, Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn has criticized an American writer, Olga Carlisle, for speaking openly and "so inaccurately, too" ...

MANILA, June 12--President Ferdinand E. Marcos opened the first session of the Philippines' new interim assembly today, calling it "a signal change in the evolution of our political life," but said that for the time being he would not lift the martial law under which he has ruled since September 1972.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Representatives of the major New York City banks and municipal pension funds refused today to commit themselves to increased lending to the city despite pressure from the Senate Banking Committee, which is considering loan legislation for the city.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)-- President Carter told a group of young Capitol Hill pages today that it he had known, when he first came to Washington, as much as they did about how to deal with Congress he might have been more successful in the last year.

WHITE PLAINS, June 12--Two psychiatrists testifying for the prosecution in the trial of Richard J. Herrin said today that the 24-year-old defendant could not be considered to have been psychotic at the time of Bonnie Joan Garland's ...

David R. Berkowitz was sentenced yesterday to the maximum prison term, 25 years to life, for each of the six "Son of Sam" slayings carried out over a year in which his nighttime forays cast a pall of fear over the young.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)--The General Accounting Office, following a study of foreign investment in United States farmland, yesterday recommended a registration of foreign landowners similar to the Immigration and Naturalization Service's registration of aliens.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)--G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Fed would probably not pay member banks interest on an estimated $28 billion in required reserves without Congressional approval.
The General Motors Corporation announced in London that it planned to establish a plant in Northern Ireland to make seat belts for G.M. cars built in Britain and the European Continent.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 12--Israel has evacuated its main invasion forces from southern Lebanon in advance of the final withdrawal deadline tomorrow, turning over its positions to Lebanese Christian right-wing militia units, Western and Arab diplomats said today.

TOKYO, June 12--The trade restrictions that Japan imposes to protect its own producers are showing signs of easing. According to American businessmen and diplomats here, Japan's, long and richly deserved reputation as an exceedingly difficult import mar ket, almost impossible to crack, is no longer entirely true.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 12 (AP)-- Rhodesian military censors prohibited the state-owned radio today from broadcasting statements by two parties to the interim regime that were critical of a battle between security forces and guerrillas in which 22 people were reported to have been killed.

Computer, airline and semiconductor issues headed lower yesterday as the stock market continued to plow through a price-correction process for sectors that showed strength earlier this spring.

WASHINGTON AN airline stewardess has perfected a way for passengers to cart their suitcases around. Deborah M. Ratchford of Arlington, Va., was granted a patent this week for a hook that fits through the luggage handles and a wheel carrier that supports the bags.

SOWETO, South Africa, June 16--The first man to come in from the night, blood trailing on the linoleum floor, had a thumb-sized stab wound on the back of his head. HACKENSACK, June 16--A prosecution toxicologist testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that there was "not sufficient scientific certainty" to say that the drug curare was present in two of Dr. Jascalevich's alleged victims.

Levi Strauss Company reported yesterday that its net income for the second quarter, ended May 28, amounted to $30.7 million, or $1.39 a share, on sales of $381 million.

Rates on six-month Treasury bills hit their highest levels in three and a half years yesterday as the credit markets sagged while they waited for today's meeting of the Federal Reserve Open Market Committee.

RALEIGH, N.C., June 18 (UPI)--Joan Little was indicted by a Wake County grand jury today in connection with her escape last October from the women's prison in North Carolina.

It vigorously denied the accusation.

WASHINGTON, June 19--Harold M. Williams, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that the agency would require corporations to file public reports on the adequacy of their internal accounting controls "at some point in the near future."

SOMERVILLE, N.J., June 19--Bart Leon of Bamm Hollow, a 23-year-old insurance salesman, carded a oneunder-par 69 and captured medalist honors among the 36 qualifiers in the New Jersey State open southern sec tionals today at Raritan Valley Country Club. The 36 who made the cat qualified for the state open July 12-14 at Canoe Brook, Summit.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP)--The National Association of Beer Importers reported that sales of imported beer, had nearly tripled since 1970 and were still growing. Though only a tiny share of the market, last year imports rose 7 percent to 78.9 million gallons. The United States Brewers Association, on the other hand, says domestic beer sales in 1977 amounted to 4.8 billion gallons--up 4.4 percent over 1976.

ROME, June 19--The case against 15 admitted members of the Red Brigades and 31 other suspects went to the jury today after the key defendants took turns reading a long statement in which they proclaimed themselves to be militant revolutionaries but not terrorists.

NASHVILLE, June 19--Clifford R. Allen, Representative of Tennessee's Fifth Congressional District and a colorful figure in Tennessee politics for 30 years, died yesterday of complications following a heart attack. He was 66 years old.
NEW BRUNSWICK, June 19 (UPI)-- Rutgers University said today it would undertake a 30-year study to trace the origins of problems that lead to problem drinking or alcoholism.

Congress seems to be perfecting a sad spring rite in which the members magisterially decide which of the nation's poor women shall be allowed Federal abortion funds. The House voted a stringent limit this week that would fund abortions only for those whose lives are actually endangered by a pregnancy. The Senate is expected to be more lenient, offering help to those whose physicians, certify that the procedure is "medically necessary."

ATLANTA, June 19--A group of bigcity mayors, worried that they are losing national influence, are trying to resurrect a device that they used some years ago to call attention to the special problems of the nation's older cities.
The Mets signed Marty Perez, veteran infielder, as a free agent yesterday and sent him to their Tidewater club in the International League. He was released earlier in the season by the Oakland A's.

The Hein-Werner Corporation, a maker of hydraulic jacks, said it had received an inquiry from a company expressing an interest in possibly acquiring Hein-Werner and had met with representatives of the company last week. It declined to identify the company and added the inquiry was "preliminary in nature."

What do you do when a movie is good but not that good and you want to put it over big? According to Norman Levy, you call in a marketing man. He happens to be one and yesterday he was named president of Columbia Pictures Distribution, a new title.

HENRIETTA, N.Y., June 19--Like a lead singer and his backup group, Perry B. Duryea and his three Republican running mates began touring upstate television studios and hotel meeting rooms today.

The first major national survey comparing the views of churchgoers with those of the "unchurched" shows considerable agreement on basic religious beliefs but sharp differences in attitudes toward organized religion.
OTTAWA, June 19--Canada indicated today that it would be willing to accept a step-by-step removal of the ban it had placed on American fishing boats in Canadian waters.
Rabbi Charles M. Batt, a Jewish community leader and businessman from West Hartford, Conn., died Saturday in Jerusalem while visiting members of his family. He was 74 years old.

A Crown Heights construction contractor whose partner was killed in a tussle with policemen last week said yesterday that the businessman and civic leader had told him of being approached by policemen seeking payoffs.

SECAUCUS, June 19--The first commuter rail station in the Hackensack Meadowlands was dedicated today, with Louis J. Gambaccini, the state's new Transportation Commissioner, and other speakers hailing the venture as a model of cooperation between government and private enterprise for the improvement of mass transit.

TOKYO, June 20--The United States dollar plunged to another postwar low against the yen in heavy trading today, closing on the Tokyo foreign exchange market at 211.60 yen, down 4 yen from the previous close.

An 18-year-old Cranford woman was found "brutally murdered" yesterday, the police said. The body of Michelle DiMarzo was found lying beside a pile of leaves at the Cranford Conservation Center, a recycling plant near the edge of the town, according to Chief Matthew T. Haney. The police reported that she had been sexually attacked.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The Government of Vietnam informed the Senate subcommittee on refugees today that it would, for the first time, allow a small group of Vietnamese women and children --who are American citizens or the spouces of American citizens--to join their relatives in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP)--Ted Sizempre was reactivated today by the Philadelphia Phillies after spending six weeks on the disabled list with broken bones in his left hand. To make room for Sizemore, Jim Morrison, a rookie second baseman, was optioned to the Oklahoma City 89ers of the American Association.

Donald Wiggins, a murderer who escaped May 30 from the state prison at Ossining, N.Y., and eluded the state police after an exchange of gunfire in Brooklyn last Thursday, was killed in a shootout yesterday at a housing project in the borough's East New York section.
A dress code has been adopted by city officials in Wildwood banning persons over the age of 12 from appearing in bahting suits in any public place except the beach.

LONDON, June 20 (Reuters)--A British attempt to scale the second-highest mountain in the world, the 28,740-foot K 2 on Pakistan's border with China, has been abandoned after the death of a climber, the expedition's sponsors said here today. They said that the name of the dead climber was not yet known and that the eight-man expedition was returning to Rawalpindi.

ATLANTA, June 20 (AP)--A Saudi Arabian businessman Gliaith Pharaon, has succeeded in his bid to buy a controlling interest in the National Bank of Georgia, formerly headed by Bert Lance, The Atlanta Constitution has reported.

Dr. George H.M. Lawrence, an internationally known botanist, died June 11 in Kent County Memorial Hospital in Warwick, R.I., at the age of 67. He lived in East Greenwich, R.I.

A new study of the reliability of atomic power plants has concluded that although nuclear reactors generally performed better last year than they had before, their performance still fell significantly short of expectations.

Bell promised Hispanic members of Congress today that the Government would speed up its handling of police brutality cases against Spanish-speaking Americans. LONDON, June 23 (UPI)--Brendan Foster, a Briton, captured the 10,000meter run at a meet here tonight in 27 minutes 30.5 seconds. Only Henry Rono of Kenya, who set the world record of 27:22.5 in Vienna 10 days ago has run the distance faster.

Bonnie Cashin is an American fashion institution. Her first poncho appeared in Hollywood in 1945 when she was designing clothes for 20th CenturyFox. Her mother sewed it up. Miss Cashin is still making ponchos.

LOUIS, July 1--The National Right to Life Committee, declaring that abortions were a prelude to a medical "holocaust," asserted this weekend that through aggressive political action, it would step up its campaign for a humanlife amendment to the Constitution to prohibit abortions except in cases in which the woman's life was endangered, and to prohibit euthanasia.

DEALE, Md., July 10 (AP)--Chase Carpenter Gove, who helped organize the United States Air Mail Service, died here Saturday. He was 95 years old.
Damages amounting to $1.2 million were assessed yesterday against the Falstaff Brewing Corporation of San Francisco for breach of contract entered in 1972 when it acquired P. Ballantine Sons.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 10 (AP)--The authorities today recovered the body of William Turbitt, a police constable who was kidnapped June 17, after receiving a tip from the Irish Republican Army guerrillas who killed him.
PAMPLONA, Spain, July 10 (Reuters) --Most of the tourists who had come here for the annual running-of-the-bulls festival had gone, and the streets today were filled with mourners.

Late this summer, the Town of Hempstead, L.I., will open a new garbage recycling plant that includes $23 million in French machinery.

Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court yesterday granted The New York Times a one-day stay of a judge's order to surrender the files of one of its reporters whose articles helped lead to the current trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, accused of murdering five hospital patients.

Corporate takeovers continued strong in the second quarter for the fourth consecutive period, W.T. Grimm Company, the Chicago merger specialist, said yesterday. Willard T., Grimm, chairman, said the yearlong surge, the first of such magnitude in 10 years, suggested "a continuing rise."

TITUSVILLE, Pa., July 11 (AP)-- Three children were killed this morning when fire swept their home near this Venango County community. The victims were identified as 5-year-old Anthony Davis, his twin sister Michelle and an 8year-old stepbrother, Duane Snodgrass. Fire officials said the blaze started near a living room fireplace.
LONDON, July 11 (AP)--About 550 striking paint-shop workers at Chrysler United Kingdom Ltd.'s plant at Linwood, Scotland, today voted against returning to work, a Chrysler spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, July 11--President Carter summoned key members of Congress to the White House today to discuss an "epidemic" of unauthorized disclosure of classified information from Capitol Hill that the President said was drying up intelligence sources and damaging national security.

A seat on the New York Stock Exchange was sold for $48,000 yesterday, down $7,000 from the previous sale July 13. The exchange said seats were currently quoted at $42,000 bid, $54,000 offered. Thirty-three seats have been sold this year.

A Florida woman who is suing Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and a physician spoke tearfully in court yesterday about her pain and anguish after she learned that a physician of that institution had destroyed a laboratory-fertilized embryo that the woman and her husband hoped would be their first child--and the world's first "test-tube baby."

A WOMAN was having lunch with a friend in a San Francisco restaurant when she suddenly got up from the table and, without a word, tottered to the ladies' room where she slumped to the floor and died. The decision of the scrappy little maestro, Billy Martin, to present "La Traviata" that night had irritated many of the company's stars, most of whom preferred to do Wagnerian opera because it kept them on stage longer than the Italian works.

A discharged employee of Citibank, New York's largest commercial bank, has filed a $14 million breach-of-employment-contract suit alleging that the bank covered up fraudulent foreign currency trading operations among its European branches.

PARIS, July 24--There's a brilliant moment midway in the Christian Dior fall couture show when a mannequin emerges in a short red dress and black suede gloves. She has a gold bracelet over one of her gloves and she carries her hands extended in a decades-old mannequin pose. Her pinky is not quite extended, but it might as well be.

Running counter to the general upward sweep in interest rates this month, yields on three-month Treasury bills dropped sharply yesterday in a decline that was largely an indirect result of the dollar's weakness in currency trading.
The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest petroleum enterprise, reported yesterday a 21.7 percent jump in second-quarter net income.

NBC's new weekday series "America Alive" made its debut at high noon yesterday and, to judge from the first installment, it appears to be a light souffle of entertainment entirely suited to the sultry weather.

WASHINGTON, July 24--Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, began a filibuster today against a bill that would remove price controls from natural gas and thus further imperiled President Carter's already troubled energy legislation.

SANTA FE, N.M., July 24 (AP)-- Western Democrats are worried about the ascent of the Republican Party in their region and say they need more money from the party and responsiveness from the White House to stop it.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 24 (UPI)-- Another West Coast pulp and paper mill was struck today, bringing to 7,000 the number of workers idled at 19 plants. Pickets from the Association of Western Pulp and Paper Workers appeared at 8 A.M. at the Newberg plant of the Publishers Paper Company. Its other Oregon mill, was struck last Friday.
WEST BERLIN, July 24 (Reuters)-- Two East German medical students have fled to the West by climbing over the Berlin wall disguised as border guards, the West Berlin government said today.

CAIRO, July 24 (Reuters)--Twentyfour people were killed and 15 injured today when an apartment building collapsed in Cairo's Sharabeya district. Interior Minister Mohammed Nabawi Ismail supervised rescue operations. Occupants of three neighboring buildings were evacuated when cracks appeared following the collapse.

TEL AVIV, July 24 (Reuters)--Israeli security forces have arrested 29 Arabs in the Gaza Strip suspected of belonging to the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, an announcement today said. The suspects were said to have planned sabotage activity in Israel and the occupied territories.

In 1972, the United States Supreme Court, in a major press ruling, held that a reporter who had witnessed a crime had the same obligation as anyone else to appear before a grand jury and answer questions.

NEWARK, July 24--The Army Department acknowledged today in Federal District Court that soldiers had been ordered to witness nuclear bomb tests, but the judge dismissed a motion that a $13 million damage suit by a former Army corporal from River Edge, N.J., who is suffering from cancer, be broadened to a class action to include all alleged victims of such Army orders.
Andre Previn, "suddenly indisposed" in England, will not appear with the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood Friday and Saturday, a spokesman for the Symphony said.

PARIS, July 24 (Reuters)--France increased its trade surplus to the equivalent of about $100 million last month from $35 million in May, the Foreign Trade Ministry said today. Exports fell to $6.4 billion in June from $6.5 billion in May, while June imports cost $6.3 billion, it said.

WASHINGTON, July 29--President Carter, responding to reports of drug use by White House employees, warned his staff today to obey the drug laws even if they disagreed with them or to "seek employment elsewhere."

RALEIGH, N.C., July 24 (UPI)-- Three more members of the "Wilmington 10" will be paroled this week and the civil rights group's leader will be granted a study release, the North Carolina Paroles Commission announced today.

FORT McMURRAY, Alberta, July 24 (AP)--In just one Canadian province, there are an estimated 300 billion barrels of oil, enough to supply Canada for 500 years or the United States for 43 years. And experts now are developing ways to mine the precious fuel.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (Reuters)-- Government officials said today that the United States trade deficit this year would probably set another record but that the monthly deficits should become smaller from now on.
The Computer Sciences Corporation announced that the Saudi Arabian Ministry of the Interior had selected it to negotiate a contract to provide a nationwide computer information system.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 (Reuters) --A filmmaking venture by five youths nearly ended in tragedy last night when Salt Lake City police officers, thinking a staged armed robbery was the real thing, fired a shot at one of them. The bullet narrowly missed.

KANSAS CITY, July 24--Dick Howser, the 5-foot-9-inch managerial bridge between Billy Martin and Bob Lemon, began tonight's game with Kansas City the way Martin had begun more and more games in the final weeks of his Yankee tenure--without Reggie Jackson in the lineup.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 24--A reporter for The New York Times was sent to jail today and the Times Company was heavily fined after both were convicted of contempt of court for refusing to obey a court order to turn over the reporter's confidential notes for possible use in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich.

Led by Commissioner Bruce C. Ratner, New York City's Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday conducted a unit-pricing sweep of 23 supermarkets. Eleven were found to be violating the price-posting law, which requires food markets to list prices per quantity in specified product categories so that consumers can compare value in different brands.

On a field where he was once booed as a bully, Pete Rose basked in a threeminute standing ovation last night in Shea Stadium when he tied the National League record by hitting in his 37th straight game.

ATHENS, July 24 (AP)--Twelve time bombs exploded today in Athens and Piraeus, the adjacent port city, on the fourth anniversary of the collapse of the Greek military dictatorship. The police said no one was hurt and there was no significant damage. They said they did not know who had planted the bombs.

Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage and investment banking firms, announced yesterday that its profits for the foruth fiscal quarter ended June 30 more than tripled to a record $6.45 million, or $l.44 a share, from $1.88 million, or 52 cents a share, in the similar period a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 24--The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates federally chartered savings and loan associations, today approved a proposal that would enable these institutions to offer four types of variable-rate mortgage.

YONKERS WE'RE here at Carvel College with John and Barbara O'Malley who are graduating in uni forms white as the vanilla. We are toasting them with pink champagne and listening to Tom Carvel's terrible voice.

THERE ARE certain things that one always says about comedians when they reach the age of 82 and are still working, but they do not easily come to mind when you meet George Burns, eating, frugally, at the Friars Club during a New York weekend that included seeing the premiere of a movie he's in and discussions of another book he's writing.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 24--Gen. Juan Pereda Asbun, who assumed the presidency of Bolivia on Friday with the support of military units, swore in a largely civilian Cabinet today. Meanwhile, opposition sources reported the arrest of at least 100 labor and student leaders and some human rights activists.
WASHINGTON, July 24--There was the beginning of a break today in the weather and in the wildcat public transit strike that has plagued the capital for the last five days.

The Times has been fined severely and our colleague, M.A. Farber, has been ordered to jail indefinitely for refusing to reveal to a New Jersey court the confidential sources of news reports. These punishments for contempt of court are so great as to intimidate the most prosperous publishers and most courageous reporters.

Governor Carey yesterday abandoned his plan to save the Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing program through subsidies to tenants and limited rent increases. He said he would send the Legislature a new plan to rescue financially ailing projects individually and would "insist" that the Legislature enact the plan when it returns on Aug. 8.
TOKYO, July 24--The rate of exchange for the United States dollar plunged today below the psychologically significant barrier of 200 yen for the first time since World War II.
TOKYO, July 24 (UPI)--Japan's production of four-wheeled vehicles reached 840,706 units in June, the second-highest level on record, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association reported today.

The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will celebrate its 20th anniversary with six revivals during its season at City Center, from Nov. 29 through Dec. 17. Dances scheduled are "Flowers," "Kinetic Molpai," "The Beloved," "Congo Tango Palace," "Toccata" and "Reflections in D."
MIAMI--The Florida Power and Light Company used to be a "growth" utility. Typically, sales jumped 13 percent a year. So did earnings.

Avon Products, the door-to-door marketer of household products, reported a 28.8 percent profit rise for the second quarter to $48.8 million, or 84 cents a share, from $37.9 million, or 65 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales climbed to $462.18 million from $360.42 million. David W. Mitchell, the company chairman, attributed the gain to an increase in the sales force.

The president of the New York-Metro Area Postal Workers Union recommended to the union's 23,000 members last night that they strike in protest against the tentative contract agreed upon last week with the United States Postal Service.

SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 (AP)--The Chilean military junta today ousted a member who had urged a speedier return to civilian rule. It was the first change in the junta since the right-wing generals overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens five years ago.

SAN DIEGO, July 24 (UPI)--The United States Coast Guard detained a Mexican fishing boat for almost 10 hours and then released it after citing it for fishing in American waters. The boat was stopped Saturday about a half-mile north of the United States-Mexican border and inside the 200-mile territorial limit.
Sports fans who love to say they were there when something important happened got their wish at Shea Stadium last night, thanks to Pete Rose.

JERUSALEM, July 24--Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan told Parliament today that Israel would undertake to discuss the sovereignty of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in five years if the Arabs meanwhile accepted the Israeli peace plan granting the inhabitants partial autonomy.

West 48th Street, with its burned-out houses and burnt-out street people, seems an unlikely place to find colorful doorways, gated patios and windows graced with hanging plants. Yet there they are, standing out incongruously on five adjacent buildings on the rubblestrewn block between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.
CLEVELAND--The change started coming to Ohio City just as Mary and John Trisco were about to give up.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP)--Patricia Hearst says that she feels she is becom ing a "professional prisoner" and wishes her jailers would not "keep telling me this is such a nice place--like I'm lucky to be here."

WASHINGTON, July 24--The Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs is expected to propose rules forbidding companies that do business with the Government to pay for their employees' membership in clubs that discriminate on the basis of sex, race or religion.

Why was the advice of George F. Bennett sought by Lee A. Iacocca last month when the president of the Ford Motor Company found himself falling into disfavor with Henry Ford 2d, the chairman and chief executive officer?

Governor Carey's office announced today that Mr. Carey had signed the omnibus anticrime bill stiffening penalties for adults convicted of violent crimes, limiting plea-bargaining and allowing juveniles accused of certain types of violent crimes to be tried in the adult criminal-court system.

RAMALLAH, Israeli-Occupied West Bank--The graying Palestinian peasant self-consciously smoothed her embroidered black dress with work-roughened hands, apologized for her lack of education and in simple Arabic talked about her 28-year-old son, held for five months in a Ramallah jail.

TORONTO, July 24--All the indications are that the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which began here three days ago and continue through Sunday, will be the world's biggest-ever tournament.

Steel production for the week ended July 22 rose to 2.59 million tons, up 0.2 percent from the week before, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The industry produced 2.58 million tons the week before.
Grants totaling $141,026 have been given to 89 nonprofit cultural organizations throughout the city by the city's Cultural Affairs Department, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

BRUSSELS, July 24--West Germany made clear today that it expected other European countries joining its proposed European currency stabilization plan to adopt conservatively inclined policies that would tend to lower economic growth, as well as inflation.

The Polaroid Corporation was the star of Wall Street yesterday as it moved ahead nearly 3 points on the strength of an enthusiastic brokeragehouse recommendation. The overall stock market, meanwhile, sagged under the weight of worries touched off by renewed weakness of the American dollar in foreign-currency dealings.

The executive council of the postal union for the New York area, whose members have shut down a bulk mail facility in Jersey City with a wildcat walkout, authorized a strike vote last night by the 26,000 union members in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, July 24--A dispute over taxation of North Sea oil profits came to light here today amid unconfirmed reports that the British Government intends to raise the basic rate of its petroleum revenue tax from the present 45 percent to 60 percent.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (AP)-- Exceller, the solid favorite, capped a brilliant season today with a comeback victory in the $164,100 Sunset Handicap on the final day of Hollywood Park's meeting.

DENVER The Christian Booksellers Associa tion, which is doing land-office business these days, recently wound up a fourday convention here that showed that the thriving industry would probably set more records next year. TRENTON, July 24--The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled 4 to 3 today that land at the bottom of a reservoir in Old Tappan should be assessed at the original purchase price of $670 an acre instead of the present market value, which could fall between $2,200 and $2,800.

About 100 people were evacuated from the building while policemen dealt with the bomb, wrapped in brown paper. No group was reported to have claimed responsibility.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the overseas transactions of Citibank, the nation's largest international banker, according to Government officials familiar with the study.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 26 (AP)--A Federal district judge ruled today that Feodor Fedorenko could keep the United States citizenship he won by concealing his past as a guard at Treblinka, the Nazi death camp.

WASHINGTON, July 26--In its first official interpretation of the Supreme Court's Bakke decision, the Justice Department has urged approval of an affirmative action program that sets strict numerical quotas for the promotion of blacks in the Detroit police department.

ALBANY, July 26--Governor Carey has signed into law a bill that could make Suffolk the first county in the state where voters could initiate their own laws through public referendums, the Governor's office announced today.

TORONTO, July 26--The National Hockey League's Board of Governors postponed decisions today on approval of the New York Islanders' refinancing plan and of Arthur Imperatore's bid to buy the Colorado Rockies.

PARIS The Curzon House Club's 1978 Backgammon Championship was held earlier this month in London. This invitational event was limited to 64 players, each paying a $1,000 entry fee. Hermes Michaelides, a Greek Cypriot, took first place by defeating John McManus of Ireland in the finals. Tom Gilbert, a top-ranked, American player, easily triumphed over Carrie Trigg to take the consolation flight.

A new theatrical production company, M-P-M Enterprises, has been formed by Arthur Penn, the director; Martin Manulis, the producer and director, and Priscilla Morgan, formerly of the William Morris Agency. The three, whose office is at 1860 Broadway, are now "reading manuscripts and talking to authors" about possible productions, Miss Morgan said.

DALLAS, July 26 (UPI)--Officials at Parkland Hospital today announced the separation of Siamese twins by surgery. Officials said that the 6-week-old twin girls were joined at the chest, stomach and pelvis. The operation began at 7:30 A.M. and lasted several hours.

BOONTON, July 26--A 65-year-old Parsippany man missing from a nursing home today became the first person to be rescued by the Air Rescue Medical Evacuation Unit of the New Jersey State Police. He was spotted crawling in a swampy area near Lincoln Park, picked up by helicopter and brought to the Riverside Hospital here.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The American Telephone and Telegraph Company took issue today with provisions in a House bill that call for the divestiture of its Western Electric subsidiary and that might jeopardize the company's national telephone switching network in the name of competition.

ALBANY, July 26--Governor Carey today signed a bill abolishing the New York City Board of Water Supply, which had been criticized for years as a "political patronage dumping ground" by mayors, legislators and "good government" groups who found themselves powerless to end it.
TORONTO, July 26--For the first time in the history of the game, the life master pair championship, which has been contested for almost half a century, has been won by a pair of women players.

The International Air Transport Association (I.A.T.A.), the airfare cartel, recently opened the door a crack to competition. It will no longer require airlines to participate in collective rate-setting to enjoy its essential housekeeping and clearinghouse services. The decision is less an endorsement of competition than a reluctant admission of division among carriers flying the Atlantic.

LONDON, July 26--The first authenticated birth of a baby conceived in a laboratory, an event that comes on the heels of other developments in reproductive control, has intensified debate among scientists that touches such issues as the sanctity of life.

LONDON, July 26--The first authenticated birth of a baby conceived in a laboratory, an event that comes on the heels of other developments in reproductive control, has intensified debate among scientists that touches such issues as the sanctity of life.

WASHINGTON, July 26--A group of noted economists, former Government officials and business executives announced today that they intended to draft a constitutional amendment to limit spending and taxation powers of local, state and Federal governments.

SAN DIEGO, July 26--Defense Secretary Harold Brown assured the South Korean Government today that the Carter Administration was committed to the "security and well-being of the Republic of Korea" and that the approaching withdrawal of American combat troops would be carried out only if the military situation warranted.

BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 26-- Their names and faces are not well known. They labor behind the scenes. They are there to blame if things go wrong, but they get none of the glory if they go right. They must be pep-talkers, excuse-makers, game analysts, alter egos, devil's advocates and, in the throes of crisis, tireless and trusted friends.

With Tommy Holmes's modern National League record safely behind him, all Pete Rose had to do yesterday was extend his league mark--and that is just what he did at Shea Stadium, with a fifth-inning double that was one of the two Cincinnati highlights in the Reds' 12-3 loss to the New York Mets.

The sex "supermarket" that opened recently across from one of New York City's delights, the Citicorp Center's Market, would be distasteful in any location, but its shabby quality is heightened by its purposeful proximity to the elegant Citicorp complex. This cluster of shops and open spaces is an oasis where the urban rambler can browse, have a cup of coffee or enjoy five minutes of quiet, alone but not lonely.

LONDON, July 26--Scientists applauded, English churchmen nodded a qualified approval and the British press turned somersaults today to welcome the world's first baby born from an egg fertilized in a laboratory.

WESTHAMPTON, L.I.,--Warm, dry wind swept over the forest, a curious forest of pine trees no more than six feet in height and even smaller oaks with shiny green leaves. A prairie warbler was singing up the scale nearby as Dr. Steven Englebright, a geologist on the staff of the State University Center at Stony Brook, stretched his arm out toward the landscape.
THEIR pieces arc always new, always one of a kind. Which is exhausting for them, fun for us, and terribly nice for the 90's.

New York City officials announced plans yesterday to prevent further illegal conversions of factory buildings to residential use and to bring "into compliance with fire, health and safety codes" the 1,000 structures that have already been illegally converted.
PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP)--The cousin of a dying man whose diseased bone marrow will not produce blood cells cannot be required to submit to a transplant, a judge ruled today.

A 25-year-old woman filed a $300,000 damage suit against New York State and City officials in Federal District Court yesterday charging false arrest, assault and a subsequent cover-up attempt by two plainclothes policemen who she says arrested her for prostitution as she walked home from a movie shortly after midnight on July 11 and dragged her through the street by her hair.

Governor Carey will appoint Gilroye A. Griffin Jr., a vice president at CBS Inc., as a member of the Emergency Financial Control Board, aides to the Governor said yesterday. Mr. Griffin would be the first black member named to the board since it was created in 1975.

After 12 quarters of steady growth, the construction industry recorded its first siginificant decline in the first quarter of this year, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McG w Hill, which monitors construction activities across the nation.

PARIS, July 26--From the time the very first model put her foot on the long runway, the excitement kept mounting at the Intercontinental Hotel this morning as Yves Saint Laurent showed his fall couture collection. This was the show everyone had been waiting for-- people had even pulled themselves away from dinner parties early so they would be in shape for it.

The Staten Island bus driver who refused to take out a bus that had a rearview mirror on only the left side because he considered it unsafe says he may appeal the recommendation of a referee for a written reprimand on his personnel record. The June 5 action of the driver, James A. Kerrigan of Stapleton, resulted in his emergence as a kind of hero to several thousand Staten Island commuters.

BOSTON, July 26--For the first time, doctors have been able to identify a single gene among the millions in a human cell and can now see whether an unborn baby is missing certain parts of its genetic blueprint, a team of researchers reported today.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 26--A Nassau County Court judge today dismissed five of 11 counts of an indictment against Dr. Mark J. Gerard, a veterinarian charged with switching the race horses Cinzano and Lebon in a betting coup.
THE Medal of Freedom was presented by President Carter yesterday to Arthur J. Gold berg for distinguished service as a Cabinet officer, Supreme Court Justice and chief delegate to the United Nations.

CONTRARY to popular belief and enduring cliches, Irish art and design is not limited to Celtic masterpieces or Water ford glass. The first image has been magnificently reinforced by the superb show of Irish art treasures that has been touring American musuems--not without mixed feelings about their absence in Dublin--with its dazzling displays of golden torques, brooches and buckles and such legendary marvels as the Books of Kells and Durrow.
WHEN I was small, I dreamed of large things: magic carpets, personal press conferences, an in vitation to have my feet immortalized in the cement outside Grauman's Chinese Theater.

The Nationwide Leisure Corporation, one of the country's largest vacation tour operators, is in financial difficulty and is expected soon to take steps to reorganize, possibly under the Federal bankruptcy statutes, according to authoritative trade sources.

The dollar continued to plummet to new lows against the Japanese yen, but gained against European currencies on foreign exchange markets Wednesday as news of the lowest monthly United States trade deficit in more than a year was announced.

Lou Piniella, who played for Bob Lemon in Kansas City and has predicted positive results under Billy Martin's replacement, got his old and new manager off to a positive Yankee Stadium start last night.
ATLANTA, July 26--"I don't know where I'm going when I die," most Southern air travelers have said at one time or another, "but one thing is sure: I'll change planes at Atlanta."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 26 (Reuters)--Rhodesia's transitional Government outlined its planned schedule today, for holding universal-suffrage elections and for the promised accession to blackmajority rule.

Thomas Hagan, one of three men serving life sentences for the murder of Malcolm X in 1965, has signed an affidavit in which he denies the two others are guilty and names four other men from New Jersey who he alleges were his real accomplices.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Senate rejected a move to repeal economic sanctions against Rhodesia today, but then decisively adopted a compromise measure setting conditions under which the President could be required to lift the sanctions in the future.

THEIR 27th-floor condominium had a spectacular view of the Hudson River, but it wasn't enough for Hubert and Ruth Clapp. They felt the 40-foot expanse of glass, together with flat white walls, lacked warmth, charm, a craftsman's touch.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP)--A Pan American World Airways jumbo jet carrying 333 passengers to London lost power in an engine on takeoff and had to dump about 100,000 pounds of jet fuel before it turned around and landed safely at San Francisco International Airport. No passengers were hurt, officials said.
Mayor Koch hired 161 new inspectors yesterday for an "overseer" program meant to root out corruption and incompetence in 30 New York City agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Department of Commerce reported today that the nation's trade deficit had been sliced in half in June, a development that brought quick expressions of pleasure from spokesmen for the Carter Administration.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 26--Gen. Juan Pereda Asbun, Bolivia's new President, said today that he would be prepared to hold new general elections in 18 months if the electoral law and registry of voters could be reformed in time.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The Senate put off until tomorrow a vote on the compromise bill for loan guarantees for New York City. It is expected to be enacted when it reaches the floor.

Roman Catholic leaders criticized all forms of artificial insemination yesterday, but many Jewish, Moslem and Protestant figures endorsed a laboratoryinduced conception so long as both husband and wife were the parents of the child.

WASHINGTON, July 26--John C. White, the Democratic national chairman, said today that President Carter's renomination would be challenged in 1980 by an "issue-oriented" candidate but not by a major figure in the party.

HAVING completed its complex agency-selection process, the Army Recruiting Command an nounced yesterday its agency for the coming fiscal year--N.W. Ayer ABH International, which has been doing the job since 1967. There are two one-year options to renew.

Noting the birth in Britain yesterday of the first confirmed human "test-tube baby," a judge in Federal District Court in Manhattan cautioned the jury hearing Doris Dei Zio's $1.5 million damage suit that the event had no bearing on her case.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 26--The lethal combination of the poorest running attack and the worst pass defense in the American Football Con ference tells the impatient Jet fans why their heroes posted a 3-11 wonlost record last season.
