WASHINGTON, July 26--The Environmental Protection Agency said today that attempts by President Carter's anti-inflation team to influence the cost of regulations were sometimes made too late and with too little understanding of laws meant to protect public health.
THE National Ballet of Canada, which has visited New York every summer since 1973, returned last night for a rather brief season through Monday at the New York State Theater.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26-- Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance came here today hoping to ease the way for Security Council acceptance of the Western plan for the independence of South-West Africa.
TRENTON, July 26--A State Senator and a top state health official acknowledged today that New Jersey was at least partly responsible for the scandalous conditions at boarding homes in the state.

BOSTON, July 26--For the first time, doctors have been able to identify a single gene among the millions in a human cell and can now see whether an unborn baby is missing certain parts of its genetic blueprint, a team of researchers reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 26--The bitterly contested legislation to revise the national labor law is still alive, but only, according to Congressional experts, by grace of artificial life support systems.
MILWAUKEE, July 26 (UPI)-- The Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee has a television commercial on its hands that might be a touch too realistic.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 26 --The Cosmos rolled to their 23d victory of the season at Giants Stadium tonight and moved into a strong position of accumulating the most points in the North American Soccer League.

HARTFORD, July 26 (AP)--Joseph Lieberman, majority leader of the Connecticut Senate, said today that he would not challenge William O'Neill in a September primary election for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

TRENTON, July 26--Resorts International suffered its first major setback at the hands of the state's Casino Control Commission today when it had to withdraw an application for 305 more slot machines for its Atlantic City casino.

The attempt to conceive a child outside the body, as in the recent British experiment that yielded a live birth two days ago, was probably unethical, a leading authority on the ethics of biomedical research said yesterday. But, he added, now that it has been demonstrated that an apparently healthy child can be produced that way, further attempts would appear to be ethical.

MOSCOW, July 26--The wife of a prominent Jewish activist received a suspended prison-camp sentence today for her part in unfurling a banner from an apartment balcony declaring, "Let us out to our son in Israel."

Newspapers around the country ran editorials yesterday on the case of The New York Times and its reporter M.A. Farber, who was fined and sentenced to jail Monday for refusing to turn over his notes and other material to the defense in the New Jersey murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, July 26 (Reuters)--Saudi Arabia's exports of crude oil in June rose slightly more than 3 percent to an average of 6.94 million barrels a day compared with May, the official Saudi Press Agency said today. Average daily exports in May were 6.72 million barrels.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Carter Administration flatly rejected today foreign advice that the fiscal and monetary brakes be slammed on harder in the United States to enhance progress against inflation.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 26--Colonial Farm's Dan Horn, carrying the highest weight of his career--127 pounds--won the $26,675 Lincroft Handicap for New Jersey-breds on the grass at Monmouth Park today.

SECAUCUS, July 26--The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission approved today a zoning change within the 32-square-mile Meadowlands district that would permit development of part of a 700-acre tract formerly designated for marshland preservation.

DENVER, July 26--Top officials of the United Mine Workers voted overwhelmingly today to quash on technical grounds a rank-and-file drive to force a recall election of Arnold R. Miller, the controversial U.M.W. president who was elected to a second five-year term last June.
ST. LOUIS, July 26 (UPI)--McDonnell Douglas Corporation has dropped a $25 million lawsuit against The New York Times and a book reviewer.

PORTAGE, Wis., July 26 (AP)-- Newly hatched mayflies swarmed onto a bridge over the Wisconsin River, forcing it to be temporarily closed while crews used a road-grading machine to clear the insects away.
LOS ANGELES--The nation's largest supermarket chain, Safeway Stores, has entered the catalogue business with 18 household items priced competitively with the catalogue giants.
JERUSALEM, July 26--Prime Minister Menachem Begin said tonight that Israel had been ordered by Egypt to withdraw, by tomorrow, its military mission based in Egypt since January.

New York City officials announced plans yesterday to prevent further illegal conversions of factory buildings to residential use and to bring "into compliance with fire, health and safety codes" the 1,000 structures that have already been illegally converted.

PARIS THE most important piece of furniture in Francois Catroux's office on the stylish Faubourg St. Honore is the telephone. And next to it sits a battery of antacid preparations and headache remedies--part of the everyday equipment of an interior designer with a foot on either side of the Atlantic.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (UPI)--An order barring reporters from talking to jurors after the Seattle trial of two selfstyled revolutionaries was overturned today by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

LOOKING in on Mostly Mozart's preconcert recital on Tuesday night, a professionally serious visitor could only be impressed by the cool, relaxed atmosphere that pervaded Avery Fisher Hall. Most of the main floor was populated--there is no reserved seating for these preludes ...

G.D. Searle Company has been accused by the Food and Drug Administration of misleading advertising for its two most important drugs, Aldactone and Aldactazide, it was disclosed yesterday.

After several years of negotiations, public hearings and procedural delays, the city Bureau of Franchises has recommended a 20-year franchise contract for a cable-television system to serve Queens.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP)-- Silvio Martinez of the St. Louis Cardinals beat the San Francisco Giants, 2-1, with a two-hitter today and stopped Jack Clark's hitting streak at 26 games.

LONDON, July 26--Scientists applauded, English churchmen nodded a qualified approval and the British press turned somersaults today to welcome the world's first baby born from an egg fertilized in a laboratory.

TRENTON, July 26--Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of the state's Casino Control Commission, today acknowledged that there had been shortcomings in the enforcement of casino regulations as a consequence of efforts to get the state's first casino opened in Atlantic City as quickly as possible.

MOSCOW, July 26 (AP)--A new English-language newspaper called Moscow News International appeared in the Soviet capital this week. The eight-page paper is being published twice a week by the editorial board of Moscow News, which already publishes a weekly in English.
Aided by a recovery in its coffee business, the General Foods Corporation reported a 12 percent increase in net income yesterday for its first fiscal quarter ended July 1.

Alfredo Escalera of Puerto Rico did the expected; but Vilomar Fernandez did the unexpected and completely surprised Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua last night in 10-round lightweight fights at Madison Square Garden.
DELTA, Utah, July 26 (UPI)--Two Air Force planes collided in midair in a combat exercise but both pilots escaped injury, military officials said.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The Senate rejected a move to repeal economic sanctions against Rhodesia today, but then decisively adopted a compromise measure setting conditions under which the President could be required to lift the sanctions in the future.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 26--A taxpayer's suit challenging the part of the state's Taylor Law that requires mandatory binding arbitration in negotiations with policemen and firemen was started today by the Taxpayers Union of Long Island.

WASHINGTON, July 26--The nation's cattle population has declined to the lowest level in six years, continuing a trend that indicates consumers will have to pay even more for their beef by the end of the year.
WASHINGTON, July 26--Senator Russell B. Long, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, predicted today that his committee "will recommend a large cut in the tax rates on capital gains."

BAGUIO, the Philippines, July 26 (Reuters)--The world chess champion, Anatoly Karpov, still struggling to prove his superiority over Viktor Korchnoi after four drawn games, decided today he must take a new look at the match--from a raised chair.

GREEN RIVER, Wyo., July 26 (AP)-- Ed Cantrell, the suspended Rock Springs Public Safety Director charged with murdering an undercover narcotics agent, was committed yesterday to the state Mental Hospital for observation.

BAYREUTH, West Germany, July 26 (AP)--Simon-Estes, the American singer, won acclaim last night in "The Flying Dutchman" at the opening of the 1978 Bayreuth Festival. He was the first black male to sing a lead role at the shrine of Wagnerian opera.

THE Washington Square Music Festival held annually in the park at the lower end of Fifth Avenue has now completed two-fifths of its 1978 five-concert schedule, but it hasn't appeared outdoors yet. The first event was held according to plan at Grace Church. The second, presented on Tuesday night, wars transferred to Eisner and Lubin Auditorium by a threat of rain that never materialized.

Lawyers for The New York Times Company and a Times reporter, M.A. Farber, were drawing up legal papers yesterday to submit to the United States Supreme Court. They are asking for a stay that would allow Mr. Farber to remain out of jail during an appeal of contempt-of-court citations that were imposed in New Jersey on Monday against the Mr. Farber and The Times.

The Treasury announced yesterday that it would borrow $2.6 billion of additional cash next week to help finance the Federal Government's deficit as it sells notes and bonds to refinance $4.38 billion of publicly held securities that will come due Aug. 15.

FARMINGDALE, N.Y., July 26-- Michael A. Rosa once told his sister Sonia that he would never live to be 30 years old. Today, at 29, he was buried here at the Long Island National Cemetery, the victim of a shooting on July 15 in corruption-plagued Rock Springs, Wyo., where he was working as an undercover policeman.

WASHINGTON, July 26--Information concerning an alleged plot to assassinate the Rev. Anger in Cyprus and Greece and a mixed reaction in Turkey were the responses to the United States Senate's decision to lift a three-year arms embargo against the Turks.

Glamour stocks and airlines issues continued to power the market higher yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead through a chart resistance level. A major copper producer, Asarco Inc. announced yesterday that it was increasing the price on copper cathodes, the industry's basic product, by a cent to 65 cents a pound, continuing the rebound of severely depressed copper prices that began about a month ago.

Continuing the pattern of varied second-quarter results for the petroleum industry, a group of major oil companies reported mixed earnings yesterday. They including: the Mobil Corporation, up 20.9 percent; the Standard Oil Company of California, down 6.9 percent; the Shell Oil Company, up 2.3 percent; the Gulf Oil Corporation, down 19.0 percent, and the Continental Oil Company, up 31.6 percent.

Court papers filed Monday by a dismissed officer of Citibank charge that New York City's largest commercial bank employed two sets of books in order to minimize its foreign-exchange earnings in Europe and shift the profits to its tax-haven branch in the Bahamas.

HERE AND THERE Russell Procope, for three decades a saxophonist with Duke Ellington, and most recently with Broadway's "Ain't Misbehavin'," leads his own quintet at 9 o'clock tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe (666-9160), Broadway and 114th Street; no cover or minimum tab.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)--Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that a fivemember commission would soon visit Vietnam to arrange for the reunion of several children separated from their American fathers after the 1975 Communist takeover.

HERE AND THERE Russell Procope, for three decades a saxophonist with Duke Ellington, and most recently with Broadway's "Ain't Misbehavin'," leads his own quintet at 9 o'clock tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe (666-9160), Broadway and 114th Street; no cover or minimum tab.
DETROIT, July 26--The Ford Motor Company reported today that second-quarter profits had surpassed last year's second-quarter record by a scant 1.8 percent.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 25--The Suffolk County Legislature voted today to grant pay increases costing $1.25 million a year to 400 deputy sheriffs and correctional officers.
WHITE PLAINS, July 26 (UPI)--A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that the 1977-78 Westchester County rent guidelines violated state law.

FORKED ISLAND, La., July 26 (UPI) --Two barges filled with oil and carbon black collided today on the Intracoastal Waterway, closing a seven-mile section of the much-traveled canal and posing a pollution threat to nearby wildlife refuges.

ONE byproduct of Proposition 13 and its aftermath may be a reconsideration of some general principles of taxation. Most of the drastic measures proposed--a cap on spending, circuit breakers for property taxes, limiting total tax revenues to some percentage of total income--lead readily to such questions as "What is a good tax?" "What should taxes accomplish?" and "Who should pay taxes?"
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 26--The prosecution's 56th and final witness in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich completed testimony today, and the state prepared to rest its case.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 26 (AP)-- Policemen escorted garbage trucks on their rounds here today to protect newly hired sanitation workers against violence by more than 175 dog catchers, airport maintenance workers and sanitation workers dismissed in a strike.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 27 (UPI)--A two-alarm fire destroyed a four-story apartment building last night, killing two children and forcing the evacuation of about 20 other residents.

DETROIT, July 27--Benson Ford, a grandson of the automobile pioneer Henry Ford and a vice president and director of the Ford Motor Company, died early today of an apparent heart attack aboard his yacht, which was docked in the Cheboygan River in Michigan. He was 59 years old.

THERE is a town that time has almost forgotten less than 20 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, a town not just steeped in colonial history, but also one that has never truly cast off the 18th century.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 27--The state rested its case at 3:30 this afternoon in the five-month-old trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich after strenuous final arguments before Judge William J. Arnold on what evidence would be admitted.

WASHINGTON, July 27--Apparent efforts by Republicans to embarrass President Carter and Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, over nominations to the Federal Election Commission broke into the open today on Capitol Hill.

WHITE PLAINS, July 27--Richard James Herrin, convicted last month of a reduced charge of manslaughter in the death of Bonnie Joan Garland, was sentenced today to a term of from eight and a third years to 25 years in prison--the greatest penalty allowed under New York State law.

The 138-year-old Orange County Fair, which begins today in Middletown, N.Y., and continues through next week, is a festival of competitions and entertainment within the traditional framework of a major agricultural exhibition.

The Caffrey Family, a bluegrass group, will perform Sunday at 8 P.M. at the old red mill in Clinton Historical Museum Village, 56 Main Street, Clinton, N.J. Tickets are $3 ($2 for the elderly and $1.50 for those younger than 12). Listeners should bring chairs or blankets. The rain date is Sunday. Information: (201) 734-4101 or (201) 7354104.

ALBANY, July 27--A bill to protect tenants in rental apartments that are converting to cooperatives or condominiums in New York City's suburbs has been approved by Governor Carey, his office announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 27--The House Ways and Means Committee tonight approved a $16.3 billion tax cut to take effect in 1979, including tax reductions for individuals averaging 5.7 percent.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)--The Senate today approved a program under which the Federal Government would offer financial incentives to hospitals that closed down unneeded services.
Frank W. Luerssen, who became executive vice president of the Inland Steel Company two months ago, has been elected president of the company, the nation's sixth-largest steel corporation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, July 27 (Reuters)--The Dutch conductor Willem van Otterloo, who led The Hague Philharmonic for 23 years and later moved to Australia, was killed today in a traffic accident near here.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 27 (UPI)-- Three minor earthquakes in less than three hours shook the populated Badger Road area on the outskirts of Fairbanks today. No damage was reported. The first tremor, measuring 3.9 on the Richter scale, was felt at 5:19 A.M. It was followed at 6:51 A.M. by a tremor measuring 3.6 and at 8:11 A.M. by one measuring 3.7.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)--The head of the General Services Administration, with President Carter's permission, today requested the resignation of the second-ranking official at the corruptionplagued agency.
TRENTON, July 27(AP)--A 63year-old Roman Catholic priest who abolished bingo games, dismantled church clubs and dropped some religious services, was dismissed from his suburban parish today.

Fire swept through New York City's historic St. Mark's-in-the-Bowery Episcopal Church at Second Avenue and 10th Street yesterday, sending the roof crashing 50 feet to the floor of the main sanctuary and destroying nine of the 179-yearold landmark's 23 stained-glass windows.

WESTPORT, Conn.--"The old paymaster is dead," Col. Michael (Mad Mike) Hoare recently lamented. He was referring to the Central Intelligence Agency, which is presently out of the mercenary recruitment business. Nevertheless Colonel Hoare, the reputed king of the mercenaries, is standing by at his headquarters in Johannesburg, South Africa.

PARIS, July 27--Alix Gres brought the fall couture showings to an amiable conclusion today in her traditional way. It was particularly appropriate for the quintessential couturiere to have the last word at a time when the couture is struggling to be born again.

Culminating a nationwide search begun last August, Dr. Michael T. Sheehan has been appointed the first executive director of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island, Thomas Schleier, president of the center's board, announced.

PARIS, July 27--Prompt and full implementation of the promises of economic expansion made by Western industrial nations at their summit meeting in Bonn two weeks ago will be necessary if these nations are to avoid slipping back into recession next year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today.

GUATEMALA CITY, July 30 (AP)-- An earthquake that struck the city of Patzu yesterday killed three persons and injured many others, the police reported today. ROME, July 30 (Reuters)--Gen. Umberto Nobile, the Italian aviator who was one of the first men to fly over the North Pole, died last night. He was 93 years old.

Nothing bizarre happened at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Without any theatrics, there was a peaceful Sunday doubleheader in the Bronx.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, July 29--Paul Bailey says he would not be around to talk about motorcycle helmets now if he had not been wearing one the day the elderly woman suddenly pulled out in front of his speeding bike.

The multiplewarhead (MIRV) missile that once promised great advantage now looms as the most menacing weapon against our underground missile force. And to meet that menace, we are drifting toward a new invention that could have the same boomerang effect.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, July 30 (Reuters)--The first general election in Marxist Southern Yemen since independence from Britain in 1967 will be held sometime in November, it was announced today. A seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was sold last Friday for $210,000, the highest ever paid for a membership on a commodity futures exchange.
A RECENT cruise from Southport, Conn., to Newport, R.I., in an open 17-foot outboardpowered boat turned out to be an inexpensive delight for several reasons.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30--The New York Apollo rebounded from their West Coast road trip with a 6-1 victory over the Indianapolis Daredevils last night in an American Soccer League match.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 30--Rhodesian forces have begun a raid into neighboring Mozambique in what is described here as a pre-emptive strike against guerrillas trying to overthrow Rhodesia's transitional Government.

Governor Carey's dramatic vow to block construction of nuclear power plants in New York State until the Federal Government comes up with an "adequate" waste disposal program seems to be primarily an exercise in election-year posturing. The problem of nuclear wastes--radioactive material that must be kept isolated for hundreds of thousands of years--is real enough and has received insufficient attention. But the Governor's gesture will contribute little to the search for a solution.

ATLANTA, July 31--The Republican Party, which shunned the support of Southern blacks during the Nixon Administration, has contracted to pay more than $800,000 to a Georgia-based group of black political consultants whose main job this year is to get black votes for white Republican candidates.

LONDON, July 31 (Reuters)--A package bomb exploded today in the offices of the British Communist Party's daily newspaper, Morning Star, slightly injuring a secretary, the police said. The police said the bomb had been left on a desk for about two hours and exploded when a secretary picked it up.

MIAMI, July 31 (UPI)--A 27-year-old refugee who fled Cuba in a homemade raft on July 23 was plucked out of the sea near Key Largo yesterday by the crew of a pleasure boat, the Xtabay. Ramon Estevez Cardova, the refugee, said that he planned to join his parents, who live in New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI)--A Federal district judge has ordered the Chicago Fire Department to promote 45 white officers to the rank of captain and lieutenant while he decides on the constitutionality of two promotion lists, according to court records.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The House narrowly rejected today an effort to ban the indirect use of foreign aid funds for Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam and Uganda after opponents had charged that such a restriction would require the United States to withdraw from international aid banks and other institutions.

GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Aug. 3-- Jerry Courville, one of the established names in Met amateur golf circles, fired a 36-hole total of 147 to win the medal as the Metropolitan Golf Association opened its 76th annual amateur championship today.

Trans International Airlines, the world's largest charter carrier, received permission from the British Government yesterday to fill its United States-bound planes with American tourists stranded in England as a result of a slowdown by French air traffic controllers.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 3 (UPI)--A convicted antiwar bomber, Karleton Armstrong, has been denied parole by a three-member panel. Mr. Armstrong, who has served six years and six months, was convicted in the 1970 bombing of the Army Math Research Center at the University of Wisconsin in which one person died and several were injured.

R.J. Reynolds Industries, the nation's largest cigarette producer, has bid more than $450 million in cash and stock for the Del Monte Corporation, the world's biggest fruit and vegetable canner, Del Monte said last night.
Fans of music alfresco will have three free events to choose from this weekend at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, L.I.
Boston's pitching staff, serving a potion stronger than sleeping pills, put the Yankee hitters to sleep late Wednesday night and early Thursday morning, then kept them snoozing last night.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI)--A Federal district judge has ordered the Chicago Fire Department to promote 45 white officers to the rank of captain and lieutenant while he decides on the constitutionality of two promotion lists, according to court records.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--The steel supports of a new Senate Office Building are rising on a vacant Capitol Hill lot, and the costs, the delays and the tempers of nearly everyone involved are mounting.
"AMERICAN BALLET THEATER," the latest in a series of lavishly illustrated ballet books from Alfred A. Knopf, is certainly a schizoid affair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)--President Carter's efforts to hold down hospital costs suffered another setback in Congress today as the Senate Finance Committee rejected an attempt to place mandatory controls on hospitals that fail to restrain costs on their own.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--A critical part of President Carter's energy legislation--a bill to remove price controls from natural gas--was in danger again tonight after a day of fast-paced political maneuvers.

New York City's three major daily newspapers said yesterday that they had reached an impasse in negotiations with the pressmen's union. They announced that they would post revised working conditions in their pressrooms next Tuesday if no agreement was reached by then.

Coney Island, playground for a million people on hot summer weekends, was closed for public bathing at 2:30 P.M. yesterday by Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis, along with Brighton and Manhattan Beaches just to the east. Rockaway beaches in Queens were reopened after a one-day closing.
Attorney General John J. Degnan announced yesterday a $967,629 Federal grant to fight Medicaid fraud in New Jersey, saying the money would allow the size of the enforcement unit to double.

July sales gains among the nation's major chains averaged about 10 percent, according to data released yesterday by the retailers adding to a bright selling picture produced over the last three months.

BAGUIO, the Philippines, Aug. 3-- Viktor Korchnoi put his head into what he thought was a lamb's mouth in the eighth game of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov here tonight, but a lion bit him.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 3--Attorneys for a weekly newspaper here sought a court order today to halt a petition drive by residents and merchants in the area to curtail commercial and legal advertising in the publication, whose editorial content they find objectionable.

CANTERBURY, England, Aug. 3-- Ecumenism is emerging as the most significant issue among Anglican bishops at the Lambeth Conference, revealing the persistent, though often hidden, power of the drive for church unity.

Terence Cardinal Cooke will officiate at a funeral service at 10 A.M. tomorrow for the Rev. George Barry Ford, who was prominent as a champion of civil rights. The service will be held at the Church of Corpus Christi, 531 West 121st Street. Father Ford died on Tuesday at the age of 92 at the Mary Manning Walsh residence at 71st Street and York Avenue.
BERKELEY, CALIF., Aug. 3--Heinz Politzer, an authority on Austrian and German literature and professor of German at the University of California here, died Sunday. He was 66 years old.

JASPER, Fla., Aug. 2 (AP)--Two convicted robbers who escaped custody and allegedly went on a six-day spree of kidnappings and robberies were recaptured yesterday after an all-night manhunt in swamps near here.
Romola Nijinsky, widow of Vaslav Nijinsky, died in Paris on June 8. She was 86 years old.
SOME investors shy away from the so-called junk bond, fearing default in the extreme and a loss of principal in any case.

FAIRFAX, Va., Aug. 3--President Carter said tonight that he wanted to protect "the so-called whistle blowers" within the Federal government--those who, he said, "see defects in our Government, defects in the law, gross waste."

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 3-- Purse Snatcher, owned by the CarrMatt Farms of Harrison, N.Y., and ridden by Mike Hunter, won classes for both second-year green working hunters and regular foxchasers yesterday and moved into the lead for both championships at the Orange County Horse show.

In his first appearance before a Congressional subcommittee since he retired from the Senate in 1975, Sam J. Ervin Jr. said yesterday that Congress "has no power to amend the past" by extending the seven-year limit established for state legislatures to ratify the equal rights amendment.

IT is not a miniseries, but a subseries, the group of six films made by independent film makers to be shown beginning Sunday night at 11 under the title "Self-Portraits" as part of "Independent Focus" on Channel 13.

OAKMONT, Pa., Aug. 3--They'll never believe it. Jack Nicklaus, the heavy favorite to win the Professional Golfers' Association championship, starts the opening round with a bogey and a double bogey and is five over par after six holes, six over par after eight holes.

Visitors to the Old Bethpage village restoration, a recreated farm community of the mid-1800's on Round Swamp Road (south of Exit 48 on the Long Island Expressway), this weekend can sample a bit of Long Island living from the days of yore.

HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--The Houston Astros announced yesterday that their third baseman, Enos Cabell, had signed a five-year contract that runs through 1982. Cabell came to the Astros in December 1974 from the Baltimore Orioles.

WHEN Corliss Taylor-Dunn sings "What Good Is Love" in the Roundabout Theater's revival of "Pins and Needles," she sounds as if she herself were jobless in 1937. Actually, she wasn't even born until 1945, but her voice carries such emotional conviction that members of the audience come backstage after her performance to tell her about their own memories of the Depression.

OPERATORS of the Roosevelt Island tramway relate the story of how an uninformed visitor in the early days of the tram alighted from the smooth aerial transport, gazed about him at the peaceful island and asked impatiently, "Where are the other rides?"
New Jersey has been rebuffed by New York in its attempt to arrange a quick compromise in the quarrel between the two states over Albany's ban on heavy long-haul trucks on Route 9W in Rockland County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)--A Federal judge refused today to accept a guilty plea, worked out between prosecution and defense attorneys, from an American connected with the bombing death of Orlando Letelier.

A team of United States experts has recommended many changes in the use and operations of the Cairo Museum, The sprawling structure on the Nile houses the world's largest collection of ancient Egyptian artifacts and is the permanent home of the treasures from Tutankhamen's tomb.
